goals.question: What is the distribution of movie ratings?
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the spread of movie ratings and identify any outliers.

goals.question: What is the most common genre of movies in the dataset?
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us identify the most popular genre of movies in the dataset.

goals.question: What is the relationship between movie budget and revenue?
goals.visualization: Scatter plot of the 'budget' and 'revenue' fields
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand if there is a correlation between movie budget and revenue.

goals.question: What is the distribution of movie runtimes?
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the spread of movie runtimes and identify any outliers.

goals.question: What is the distribution of movie release years?
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the trend of movie releases over time.

code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd
def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['rating'] = pd.to_numeric(data['rating'], errors='coerce')
    plt.hist(data['rating'], bins=20, color='green', edgecolor='black')
    plt.axvline(data['rating'].mean(), color='red', linestyle='dashed', linewidth=1, label=f"Mean: {data['rating'].mean():0.2f}")
    plt.axvline(data['rating'].median(), color='blue', linestyle='dashed', linewidth=1, label=f"Median: {data['rating'].median():0.2f}")
    plt.legend()
    plt.title("What is the distribution of movie ratings?", wrap=True)
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['genre'].value_counts().plot(kind='bar')
    plt.title('What is the most common genre of movies in the dataset?', wrap=True)
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd
def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['budget'] = pd.to_numeric(data['budget'], errors='coerce')
    data['revenue'] = pd.to_numeric(data['revenue'], errors='coerce')
    plt.scatter(data['budget'], data['revenue'])
    plt.title('What is the relationship between movie budget and revenue?', wrap=True)
    plt.xlabel('Budget')
    plt.ylabel('Revenue')
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd
def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['runtime'] = pd.to_numeric(data['runtime'], errors='coerce')
    plt.hist(data['runtime'], bins=20, color='green', edgecolor='black')
    plt.axvline(data['runtime'].median(), color='red', label='Median: {:.2f}'.format(data['runtime'].median()))
    plt.xlabel('Runtime')
    plt.ylabel('Frequency')
    plt.legend()
    plt.title('What is the distribution of movie runtimes?', wrap=True)
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd
def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['release_year'] = pd.to_datetime(data['release_year'], format='%Y', errors='coerce')
    data = data.sort_values(by='release_year')
    data = data.groupby('release_year').size().reset_index(name='count')
    plt.plot(data['release_year'], data['count'])
    plt.title('What is the distribution of movie release years?', wrap=True)
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)
